title.narrative: FGG SOMO ToC 3: Improved Financial and Tax Systems

description.narrative: One of SOMO's long-term goals within the Fair, Green and Global Alliance, is to ensure that financial systems, tax regimes and public financing practices advance socially just, inclusive and environmentally sustainable development. We believe that financial and tax regimes can secure revenues and domestic resources for governments, promote equality and stability, and generate public financing that serves development goals. SOMO contributes to this goal through strategies on improving financial regulations, progressive revenue raising and spending through tax justice, and public funds for the private sector. Activities include doing research, capacity building, advocacy, organizing public events, facilitate the exchange of information, filing complaints at judicial or non-judicial complaint mechanisms, and contributing to the activities of the other FGG members. The work in this program is organized in dossiers to enable cooperation between alliance members. The specific activities of SOMO are described below. Within the dossier Regulating a financial sector that supports sustainable development by raising the voice from the South, SOMO together with the other FGG Alliance members will monitor and raise awareness about international and EU financial regulation that has the potential to exacerbate financial instability or does not go far enough in curbing it and develop accessible information materials and distribution channels. SOMO will, by contributing to its coordination and strategic orientation, also work on consolidating an international network of partners into a network that effectively raises the civil society voice at international and EU levels with the aim of improving access to decision-making about financial regulation and making voices of resistance to proposed reforms heard. SOMO supports Friends of the Earth in working on regulating European private financiers who are providing financial services to land grabbing companies outside Europe. FoE and SOMO will continue to identify current and upcoming legislation on financial regulation that can be used to introduce relevant regulation. In the dossier Developing alternative ideas and increasing support for a sustainable financial sector in developing countries, SOMO will work on a stable financial sector at the service of sustainable development in order to tackle poverty in developing countries. SOMO and Both ENDS in cooperation with Southern partners, will identify, investigate, and distribute information about alternatives to the current financial sector model. SOMO will cooperate with partners to identify and develop alternative-based partner experiences and measures that make the international financial system less risky for developing countries. In the dossier Progressive revenue raising through tax justice, SOMO and her partners will use the mapping of harmful tax policies and treaty provisions (implemented in another project) that lead to tax revenue losses in Indonesia for popularization, lobby and advocacy activities. Results will be widely shared through an open data portal and data visualisations in collaboration with SOMO's partners, investigative journalists and selected media outlets. With joint lobby and advocacy in the Netherlands, Indonesia and internationally, the project addresses the role and impact of tax and investment policies and treaties in order to end the harmful impact of the international investment regime as a whole. In the dossier Enforcement of private sector standards for development finance and access to remedy, SOMO, together with Both ENDS will continue to support communities and workers as advisors when filing complaints to the independent accountability mechanisms. In filing complaints to Development Finance Institutions, SOMO and Both ENDS will seek to partner with national and regional CSOs in order to transfer knowledge so that they themselves can support the local communities when filing complaints at to Development Finance Institutions. SOMO will continue to convene meetings with the independent accountability mechanisms (IAM) network to discuss CSO proposals for measures they can take to protect human rights defenders who file complaints.
A range of alternative, people-driven, inclusive and sustainable approaches to the current financial and tax regime have been developed and advanced by civil society actors.

comment.narrative: *A report on the harmful effects of QE on developing countries was written with the input of two Argentinean economists. The report is significant, because it is the first to point to the systemic character of the current debt crisis and how it relates to monetary policies in developed economies. The report was presented at a conference that was organized by SOMO and 8 partner organizations from Argentina. The name of the conference was People 20/Pueblo 20 and attracted around 80 people that contributed in presentations, discussions and in drafting a statement. The conference was also co-organized by the Latin American tax justice network that covers different LLMIC countries. The report was the basis for an alternative proposal due to its active participatory engagement, and led to the drafting of a call to curb capital mobility and support the UNCTAD Sovereign Debt Restructuring Mechanism (SDRM) at the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires. The role of FGG was to put the issue on the agenda.

In 2017, through active participatory initiatives together with local partners, 4 alternative proposals to financial and tax regimes are supported in influential areas by 5 LLMICs CSO and governments in the G20. SOMO contributed to the development and presentation of alternative demands in four different areas of financial policy such as 1: financial architecture,2: debt, 3: socially and environmentally sustainable finance, as well as 4: tax, anti-money laundering, corruption. Twenty-four NGOs of which 8 Southern NGOs (of which five from LLMICs) contributed directly in a governmental meeting, as well as indirectly at a meeting co-organized by SOMO. Statements were presented to change the financial system. The alternatives from civil society based on the C20 Finance working group were presented to the G20 Ministers of Finance through the created official channels between the C20 and G20. The decisions of the G20 on finance have an important effect on LLMICs although governments of LLMICs have no place at the G20.

comment.narrative: "Steps were taken to improve two grievance mechanisms – the Interamerican Development Bank's (IDB) MICI (Independent Consultation and Investigation Mechanism of the IDB) and the Independent Complaints Mechanism of FMO/DEG – through which CSOs and communities can resolve grievances. The Interamerican Development Bank's (IDB) MICI (Independent Consultation and Investigation Mechanism of the IDB) created a new external stakeholder advisory board, an official channel for civil society to provide input on the functioning of the mechanism. SOMO contributed to the result through research (the joint publication Glass Half Full), advocacy and through financial and technical support of an Argentinian CSO to work on the MICI and IAMs in general. SOMO supported the Argentinian CSO’s research for Glass Half Full, a brochure on the MICI, and research on a potential complaint. FMO/DEG adoped (in 2016) a new policy for their Independent Complaints Mechanism (published in 2017) that includes some improvements. SOMO provided substantial input into FMO’s revision, including drafting the civil society comments and attending meetings with FMO."

SOMO staff was appointed by the EC to serve on the High-Level Expert Group.

comment.narrative:
(1) In June 2020, the International Finance Corporation published the report of the External Review Team on IFC/MIGA's Environmental and Social Accountability Framework. The report made very strong recommendations to ensure adequate consultation with communities affected by IFC-financed activities, improve transparency, and consider establishing a remedy fund. It also made recommendations to enhance the procedures of the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman. The report is part of a review that was launched in 2019. SOMO was one of the members of the Reference Group established to provide information to the External Review Team. SOMO provided ongoing input to members of the Team. SOMO's publications, including "Glass Half Full" and "Best of...IAMs" were referenced repeatedly in the report.
(1) In January 2020, the Dutch Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Finance requested that SOMO organized a workshop on the independent accountability mechanisms of development finance institutions. More than a dozen ministry staff participated in the day-long workshop. We discussed best practices, trends, and several case studies. The discussion revolved for example around what consequences IAMs can expect from new contexts, such as increasingly operating in fragile contexts / risk prone environments and climate change and how to adapt institutionally and organizationally to these consequences? Working with specific cases studies the participants also walked through elements of accessibility, admissibility, responsiveness, chain of responsibility and conflict/gender sensitivity. We collaborated with Both ENDS, CEE Bankwatch Network, and Oxfam Novib on the workshop. Accountability Counsel also gave a virtual presentation.
(1) In July 2020, the External Review of the African Development Bank's Independent Review Mechanism (IRM) was published for public comment. Civil society has criticized the IRM for its delays and lack of independence. The External Review report was more comprehensive and analytical than the previous review of the IRM, serving as a very strong basis for the rest of the review process. It repeatedly references "Best of...IAMs", a report lead by SOMO which concludes with two sets of recommendations. The first set seeks to perfect the current system by identifying best practices that should be adopted by all IAMs and DFIs. The report determines, however, that simply adopting best practices will not be enough to ensure that complainants receive remedy for the harms that have occurred. Rather, a new accountability system must be established as a matter of urgency with mechanisms that are empowered to make binding decisions and DFIs that no longer claim immunity in national courts. There were only a few major issues in the report with which CSOs disagreed. One of the most important issues is the need to restructure the mechanism. SOMO provided input to the consultants undertaking the external review.
(1) In July 2020, the draft Review Report of the AfDB's IRM was published for public comment. While the draft report was very strong, there were a few issues that CSOs thought it missed. Critical among those was the need to restructure the mechanism from a "roster model" to an office headed by a senior-level director that oversees all of the mechanism's functions. SOMO, Both ENDS, a Senegalese CSO and Accountability Counsel, submitted comments as part of the consultation period. We also discussed our inputs with the consultants, the director of the IRM, and the Dutch constituency office at the AfDB. In December 2020, the external consultants published proposed reforms to the African Development Bank's Independent Review Mechanism (IRM) that reflect comments that SOMO and its partners submitted in the consultation on the draft Review Report.

(3)SOMO initiated and organized a conference in Argentina, Buenos Aires on financialization in the global south, covering subjects such as global financial structure, objects and domains of financialization and the politics and governance of financialization in developing countries. In was a unique gathering of CSOs (1), academics (1) and policy makers (1) during which the problems of financialization in the global south such as e.g. public debt management and tax avoidance were discussed. (1)In her remarks to the World Bank's Development Committee at the 2019 Annual Meetings, Minister Kaag voiced her support for an independent accountability mechanism in line with the best practices of other multilateral development banks. Her remarks came in the middle of heated discussions on the Board about reforms to the Inspection Panel that would have undermined its effectiveness and independence. Including a reference to accountability in the minister's remarks demonstrated the political importance the Dutch government gives to the issue. SOMO has been engaging closely with the ministry and the Dutch Executive Director's office throughout the Inspection Panel review and requested that the issue be included in the Minister's remarks. (3)Three editorials to the Financial Times (1), and speaking twice at UN official fora (Finance for Development ECOSOC Forum plenary, April 2019 (1), High Level Forum on Sustainable Development, July 2019 (1)) helped to raise the debate for different and more stringent regulations at national and international level. At the same time, CSO Madhyam has published 7 briefings, blogs and commentaries on particular problems of financial instability that harms LLMICs. These papers were supportive of other activities to support and build capacity of NGOs to make policy proposals to make the financial sector contributing to sustainable development rather than financial crisises. The Madhyam website with all these publications is visited by 100.000 hits a month. The Wire and the FT are having millions of readers. Madhyam worked on the above issues with Third World Network, Bread for the World, SOMO, Civil Society 20.

*In 2018 SOMO in cooperation with Tax Justice NL created a campaign to stop the abolishment of the dividend tax. Through its plans to abolish the dividend tax and lower the corporate income tax rate, the Netherlands initiated further steps in the global ‘Race to the Bottom’. The Netherlands is the world's largest conduit center, measured by FDI flows. This position as tax haven is related to the Dutch tax regime in which royalties and interest on outgoing capital flows are tax free. If the dividend tax would be abolished this would have strengthened the position of the Netherlands as a tax haven. LLMIC countries are one of the main victims of global structures for tax avoidance, because of the large relative size of corporate income tax. Therefore this campaign to stop the race to the bottom in the Netherlands is of direct relevance for developing countries. SOMO in 2018 increased public awareness and political attention on the role of the Netherlands in the race to the bottom by publishing research on this, joining a TJNL campaign and working with CSOs and politicians to put this topic on the political agenda.

5 proposals for improvement of financial, tax and spending policy and related policymaking processes were put on the public agenda, discussed by private and public policymakers, academics, media and social movements. First, through the report A structural problem in the shadows: lobbying by banks in the Netherlands, SOMO put on the agenda of Dutch policymakers and media a proposal for transparency and greater civil society influence, relative to banks, in decision-making processes around financial laws so as to better support public interests, including contribution to more sustainable, just and inclusive societies worldwide. SOMO also helped put this issue on the agenda at the European level through participation in ‘The representation of public interest in banking’ conference organised by Finance Watch on 7 December 2016 in Brussels, with 120 participants. The conference brought together academics, government officials of the European Commission, private sector and CSOs. Second, recommendations for making the financial sector more stable and socially and environmentally sustainable were put on the agenda of a global network of CSOs. In December SOMO co-organised a conference for CSOs attended by 45 organisation from around the world on financial sector reforms. SOMO partners from India, Indonesia and Ghana made important contributions to the conference’s discussions and recommendations, which were presented in a letter to the G20 Presidency and the German Minister of Finance. Third, in November 2016, the Board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development discussed recommendations on accountability and access to remedy for communities and workers adversely affected by bank-financed activities. The recommendations were made by SOMO and co-authors of the Glass Half Full report. Fourth, in May 2016, the same issues were discussed in relation to the Asian Development Bank by a panel at the annual meeting of the ADB and by members of the ADB board. Responsible disengagement is on the agenda with FMO/ NUON, Dutch Government, as result of the Should I stay, Should I go paper and complaint handling of the Agua Zarca complaint.

In 2017, SOMO and its local partners were able to provide 8 proposals for improvement of financial, tax and spending policies have been discussed by private and public sector decision makers. This was done through improvement measures due to influential civil society actors, critical media attention increased public awareness and effective scrutiny of financial and tax policies together with local partners. For example, a proposal was aimed at providing access to grievance mechanisms within the context of shrinking civic space, one large major bank responded to the joint NGO letter expressing its interest to engage in dialogue on an enabling environment for meaningful, safe and effective public participation and respect for human rights. It expressed its intention to review concrete projects to draw lessons on how due diligence and stakeholder engagement can be improved. These proposals were diffused by SOMO’s ability to engage stakeholders in both public and private realms in order to enable meaningful, safe and effective public participation and respect for human rights.

2016-2017 2 proposals for improvements of financial, tax and spending policies discussed by private and public policy makers, and social movements.
2019: *By the end of 2019 SOMO and its partners will have had 1 meeting with political parties in the Dutch parliament, 1 in the EU parliament and 1 in the Dutch senate. Due to these meetings, the aforementioned actors will discuss 3 proposals for improvement of financial policies concerning subordinated financialization that have been developed in the previous year by Tax Justice NL, with the aim to decrease the negative effects of the monetary policy by the ECB, through parliamentary questions resulting in legislative proposals in 2020. *In 2019, 2 proposals for improved Development Finance Institutions human rights policies are being considered by FMO and 1 other Development Finance Institution, including investments in financial intermediaries after lobby and advocacy by SOMO and partner organisations. *By the end of 2019 SOMO with the network organisation Tax Justice NL [members are Milieudefensie, Foundation Max van der stoel, FNV, SOMO, BothEnds, Oxfam Novib, ActionAid and TNI] contribute to 1 proposal, which will be discussed by Dutch policy-makers, aimed at contributing to the fight against tax evasion and a fiscal system that is coherent with international development goals and goals for sustainable development. Tax Justice NL aims to influence the Dutch policy on tax evasion, to evaluate the policy and to the make the policy measurable (proof by numbers). The aim is to reach policy change in 2020.
2020:
(1) In 2020, two SOMO research briefings on shortcomings in Dutch and international policy proposals to combat tax avoidance, and how this affects LLMICs, will be discussed in Parliament and the media which contribute to agenda setting of this issue.
(2) two proposals (1 concerning corporate financialization and 1 concerning monetary policies) will be published and presented at a seminar to be discussed by policymakers and/or academics and/or media. The reason to organize this is to represent the interest of LLMIC countries in both topics.
(1) In 2020, government ministries in multiple countries will discuss and consider a proposal for improving independent accountability mechanisms (IAM) of Development Finance Institutions (DFIs), based on the recommendations in the IAMs Best Practice (Good Policy) report, which is coordinated and co-written by SOMO.

description.narrative: Increased capacity of civil society actors to research, network and advocate on financial and tax policies.
# CSOs and communities in LLMICs that lobby and advocate for improved financial, tax and spending policies, based on increased skills, knowledge or network contacts.

comment.narrative: (1)The Foundation for the Development of Sustainable Policies (FUNDEPS) hosted the 2019 retreat of the International Advocates Working Group (IAWG) in Cordoba, Argentina. SOMO had hosted FUNDEPS staff in 2018 to help us prepare the IAWG retreat that we co-hosted in The Netherlands. We had also provided financial support to help them organize the retreat and provided input on the planning. Everything from the logistics to the content of the meeting was excellent. In the opening remarks, FUNDEPS credited SOMO for helping them expand their expertise on the IAMs and making it possible for them to host the retreat. (3)SOMO contributed to strengthening CSOs RIAO-RDC (DRC), East Africa Center for Human Rights (Kenya), and a community in Guatemala through ADVICE ON filing cases to the complaints mechanism of the German development bank (DEG) and the International Finance Corporation’s Compliance Advisor Ombudsman, respectively. (3)During a conference on financialization in the global South universities and CSOs shared and learned from each other, lobbying for improved financial systems. SOMO was co-organiser of this conference. Among the various presenters were three CSOs (Fundacion Nodo XXI (Chile), International Gender and Trade Network (Argentina, Brazil), Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung (Germany)) whose skills were mutually strengthened.

(2) SOMO had been working with two CSOs that are working towards fairer tax treaties with high-income countries. One of them filed ten tax treaties at the Kenyan Supreme Court of Justice. SOMO provided technical assistance in developing the argument that the Dutch tax treaties, amongst others with Kenya, are not in the general interest of Kenya. Currently, the Kenyan Court of Justice is reviewing the tax treaties that the CSO filed. SOMO has supported the other CSO with input on how, and through which means, the new tax treaty with the Netherlands that is currently being negotiated, could be improved. The organisation is involved in these negotiations.
In May 2020, the World Bank Inspection Panel registered a complaint from community members in Nepal regarding the environmental and cultural impacts of a dry port project financed by the World Bank. The dry port will have environmental and social impacts on neighbouring communities, which were not effectively consulted either. (1) A Nepalese CSO, supports the community in its complaint. SOMO has provided advice to the CSO on drafting the complaint, follow up with the Panel and the Board of Directors, and participated in calls with the Panel. Unfortunately, the Panel has delayed its eligibility determination until it can take a site visit, which is not currently possible due to the pandemic.
The particulars of the civil claim against Camellia (parent of Kakuzi) were filed in the UK, in October 2020. Leigh Day filed the case on behalf of 79 (former) workers and inhabitants of the Kakuzi plantation in Kenya. SOMO supported the development of the case through research, documentation, and by supporting (financially and through training) local communities to organize and document. We worked together with two CSOs in providing this support. Both CSOs are a major source of information, knowledge and connections in the local context and form the link between SOMO (and Leigh Day) and the communities. They have also done extensive public advocacy in the context of the lawsuit, incl. around the demands of the claimants and larger communities, and around the intimidation by the company experienced by the claimants – which stopped, following public exposure in the Sunday Times.

*(3) In April, SOMO, together with Both ENDS and Bank Information Center Europe hosted third annual retreat of the International Advocates Working Group, attended by 35 participants, including CSO representatives from Uganda, Senegal, Mongolia, Colombia, Argentina, and the Philippines. Several new CSOs attended the retreat and learned about IAMs and how to use them. CSOs from Senegal, Mongolia and the Philippines have used these skills in their complaint work and policy advocacy. We organized the retreat and mobilized resources from other organizations to cover the travel expenses of attendees.
SOMO expected 2 more CSOs to be strengthened to be able to lobby and advocate for improved financial, tax and spending policies. Instead, partners’ skills were strengthened to advocate for improved trade policies. Therefore, this result is reported under 2.B. Furthermore, SOMO organized a knowledge building seminar on capital controls in which other partners participated than expected (not from LLMIC). It was a successful seminar but we have no evidence yet that the built knowledge translated into active lobbying for improved financial, tax and spending policies.

8 CSOs and communities in Indonesia, Ghana, India, Mongolia, Honduras, Senegal, Nicaragua, Argentina and Bolivia increased skills, knowledge or network contacts for lobbying and advocacy for improved financial, tax and spending policies. SOMO supported an Indonesian CSO to increase knowledge and research skills on tax and investment policies that are potentially harmful to Indonesia’s tax base, as well as to identify specific corporate structures potentially used for regulatory avoidance. The group has strengthened its capacity to advocate together with other Indonesian CSOs to close loopholes that lead to regulatory taks avoidance and thereby increase Indonesia’s tax base. SOMO supported two CSOs in Ghana and India to identify risks of the international financial system for developing countries and develop alternative measures to decrease these risks. The groups participated in an international meeting in Berlin (8-9 December 2016) of the international NGO Finance Network where they exchanged knowledge and skills. The Indian CSO lobbied for a new Indian law government against increased speculative trading on commodities. SOMO strengthened the capacity of another six CSOs (in Mongolia, Honduras, Senegal, Nicaragua, Argentina and Bolivia) to file complaints on specific cases (projects) and advocate for improved policies of development finance insititutions based on these cases.

In 2017, SOMO has lobbied and advocated for improved financial, tax and spending policies with 8 CSOs. These activities were based on increased skills, knowledge or network contacts developed in the increased capacity building of CSOs to research, network and advocate on financial and tax policies. Specifically, SOMO has provided financial and substantiated support in a series of negotiations on the Compliance among workers, resettlements and lack of community engagement in southern countries.

# concrete steps taken by public financial institutions and private actors to actively identify, prevent and mitigate adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of their investments, and concrete steps taken that advance socially just and sustainable development in LLMICs.

comment.narrative: (1) In August, a Nicaraguan environmental justice organization signed a supplemental agreement with a corporation that owns sugarcane plantations in a dialogue process in Nicaragua facilitated by the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman (CAO) of the International Finance Corporation. This supplemental agreement responded to the urgent needs of the members of the organisation due to the COVID 19 pandemic and provided for three distributions of food for all of its members. This was in addition to the packets of hygiene supplies (hand sanitizer, soap, etc.) that the company had already provided.

(1)The Independent Complaints Mechanism (ICM) of the Dutch and German development banks has been monitoring the Barro Blanco project since 2015 when it published its compliance review report. The complaint was originally filed in 2014 by the Movement 10 Abril (M10), with support from SOMO and Both ENDS. The ICM was going to close the case without undertaking a site visit or re-visiting its initial non-compliance findings, this decision was based on an unpublished monitoring protocol that it has negotiated with the banks in 2019, which we believed contradicted the ICM's policy. In response to a letter and conversations we (SOMO, Both ENDS , and M10) had with the ICM and FMO highlighting these concerns, the ICM decided to take a site visit to Panama and revise its report on that basis. (1)In December 2019 Shell published the first Tax Contribution Report. The report shows how much tax Shell pays in the countries it is operating in. This enables CSOs and the general public to analyse how much tax Shell pays in their country (e.g. Nigeria) and take the company or government to task for tax avoidance. The report also sets an example for other companies to follow. Country-by-country reporting has been a key ask of CSOs in the field of tax justice for years and it is a big step forward that Shell now publishes this. Furthermore, Shell also finally admitted that it pays no corporate income tax in the Netherlands. SOMO contributed to both these developments by years of work on tax justice and country-by-country reporting, and by publishing research in 2017 and 2018 that showed how Shell avoids the dividend tax. This contributed to much public and political outcry over Shell's tax morale. The move by Shell to publish the tax contribution report and admit it pays no corporate income tax can be seen as partly a response to this. (1)In November, the Board of Executive Directors of the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) approved an international investigation of the Bank’s private lending arm, IDB Invest, for its investment in the Ituango hydroelectric project. Located in the department of Antioquia, Colombia, the Ituango dam has had a devastating impact on thousands of people across four departments and 27 municipalities in Colombia. The Board had previously refused to approve the investigation of its public-sector financing of the project. The complainants, Movimiento Ríos Vivos, are supported by the Interamerican Association for Environmental Defense (AIDA), the Center for International Environmental Law (CIEL), and the International Accountability Project (IAP). SOMO provided financial support to AIDA and some advice.

*(0) In June, communities in Colombia filed a complaint to the mechanism of the Inter-American Development Bank, the MICI, regarding a hydroelectric project.The case involves serious security concerns for the complainants, forcing the mechanism to take concrete steps to deal with security issues. It is also one of the first complaints about the private sector lending arm of the IDB. SOMO provided financial support and advice to a CSO in Colombia who is supporting the complainants. *(1) In November 2018, the textile cooperative in Nicaragua, which was the result of an agreement between a CSO in Nicaragua and Corporacion Montelimar under the auspices of the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman, was officially launched and generated a profit, which was used to benefit its members and widows of those who had already died of chronic kidney disease. SOMO provides financial support and advice to AMBED on a very regular basis. *(1) Research by SOMO and Bank Information Center Europe on the impacts of the International Finance Corporation’s (IFC) investment in a cement plant and coal mine in Myanmar was used to inform a mission undertaken by USAID and the monitoring visit to the cement plant by the IFC and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. The concerns of the community members were being ignored by the financiers. We undertook the research in Myanmar and communicated the findings to the World Bank Group through a presentation at the World Bank annual meeting and meetings with the Executive Directors of the World Bank.

comment.narrative: In February, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that international organizations, like the World Bank's International Finance Corporation, do not enjoy absolute immunity in U.S. courts. Instead, they can be subject to suit when they are engaging, among other exceptions, in commercial activities. The decision is important because until now, it thought that the World Bank's articles of agreement barred any lawsuits against it in the courts of its member states. The complainants in the case are affected by an IFC-financed coal power plant in India. They were represented by Earthrights International. SOMO was one of nine organizations who submitted a joint amicus brief to the U.S. Supreme Court in the case and provided a declaration with the original filing in 2015.

comment.narrative: 2 measures taken by national government bodies to change relevant current and upcoming legislation on financial regulation and change investment, tax treaty negotiations and the fiscal regimes in order to advance socially just and sustainable development in LLMICs. First, the G20 Green Finance Study Group full report with proposals for voluntary initiatives was adopted at the G20 Summit in September 2016 as a means of mobilising private capital for green investment and supporting global sustainable growth. The German G20 presidency will integrate green finance issues in some way from December 2016 onwards. After Commissioner Hill, responsible for financial regulation and stability (DG FISMA), left in June 2016, the new responsible Commissioner, Mr Valdis Dombrovskis, has dynamically taken up the issue of green finance. As a result, there are several initiatives to ensure that investments carried out under the new rules of the Capital Markets Union are more supportive of, and take the lead in, financing a carbon-free economy and, in the longer term, take social and governance issues (ESG) into account. Second, the US government made an official statement at the World Bank Board calling on the IFC to develop stronger action plans in response to the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman's investigations.

In October, Asociacion Montelimar Bendicion de Dios (AMBED) signed a final agreement with Corporacion Montelimar in a dialogue process in Nicaragua facilitated by the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman (CAO) of the International Finance Corporation. The final agreement builds on the initial agreement, signed in 2017, and provides for health care services for some of the community; a textile cooperative to provide economic benefits to AMBED's members; regular distribution of food to AMBED members, participatory water quality monitoring, and a strengthened grievance mechanism. SOMO has provided AMBED with financial resources and extensive support and advice throughout the complaint process and was present for the signing of the final agreement

Through research and corporate investigation together with local partners, SOMO ensured that 2 measures were taken by an EU government body to advance socially just and sustainable developments in LLMICs in 2017. The first measure indicates where SOMO provided the investigative foundations that led to an EU based investigation on large commercial goods/furniture store. The second measure SOMO provided a clear measure of information and data through SOMO’s in-depth knowledge and research material on EU governmental bodies, thus ensuring financial, tax and spending policies to advance socially just and sustainable developments.

comment.narrative: (1) In March 2020, the World Bank Board of Directors approved a set of reforms that strengthens the mandate of the Inspection Panel. The Inspection Panel was the first independent accountability mechanism created at a development finance institution. While far from adopting innovative changes that would have set the bar for public accountability in development finance, the Board did approve tools, such as a dispute resolution function, that are well-established practice at other IAMs. However, the reform package also included structural changes that could undermine the independence of the Inspection Panel as well as the effectiveness of the system as whole. Ultimately, the effectiveness of these reforms will depend, in part, on the Board’s commitment to ensuring the independence of the new Accountability Mechanism and to making any adjustments necessary as the new system is operationalised.. Despite protests from civil society, the process that led to these reforms had very little opportunity for public consultation. SOMO engaged with the Dutch ministry and Executive Director, as well as the other European Executive Directors, throughout the process, providing feedback and suggestions for improvement.

*(1) In November 2018, the European Investment Bank (EIB) approved a new policy for its Complaint Mechanism that included better oversight by the Board of Directors and several provisions found in the earlier draft that would have undermined the mechanism’s independence were removed or modified. The EIB is a very large investment bank, supporting projects around the world. Ensuring that its grievance mechanism is effective is critical. SOMO helped prepare the joint CSO submission (7 of which in LLMIC) on the draft policy, participated in the consultation, and provided input to the Dutch Ministry of Finance.
*(1) In October 2018, the World Bank Board of Directors approved reforms to the Inspection Panel in order to: “(i) formally recognize the Inspection Panel’s advisory role in its mandate; (ii) issue clarifications on the use of Bank-Executed Trust Funds (BEFTs); (iii) formalize the Panel’s current practice to coordinate with the accountability mechanism of cofinancier(s) to process the complaints in the most efficient and effective way possible; and (iv) update the procedures for sharing the IPN’s Investigation Report with requesters ahead of the Board meetings.” The Inspection Panel was the first independent accountability mechanism created and has not changed much in the last 25 years. These reforms, while imperfect, addressed some gaps. SOMO met with the Dutch ministry, contributed to a CSO submission and participated in a listening session organized by the Board.
*(1) In December 2018, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) approved a policy creating a new complaints mechanism (Project-affected People’s Mechanism) that was substantially better than the previous drafts. The AIIB is a new economic player, created by China. It was not certain whether they would develop a complaints mechanism or whether that mechanism would be any good. This complaint mechanism would benefit LLMICs to which the AIIB lends. SOMO led the drafting of the CSO submissions, participated in consultations, met with the Dutch and British governments, etc.
*(1) In June 2018, Dutch export credit agency Atradius Dutch State Business (ADSB) approved Guidelines for Submitting a Complaint, which while not sufficiently robust to be considered an independent accountability mechanism marks the first export credit agency to have a formal complaint process. This complaint process can benefit communities in several LLMICs. SOMO met with Atradius, together with Both ENDS and TNI, to discuss best practice. We jointly provided comments on a draft.
*(1) In September 2018, the Board of the World Bank Group did not approve a change in the reporting line of the Compliance Advisor Ombudsman (CAO) that was proposed by the International Finance Corporation’s (IFC) and would have undermined the CAO’s effectiveness. The CAO is the most effective IAM that we have and benefits communities in LLMICs to which IFC lends. The changes would have started to unravel the office. SOMO communicated with the Dutch government to inform its position at the Board of the World Bank Group.
*(1) In October 2018, the International Finance Corporation (IFC) committed to further reforms of its financial intermediary (FI) lending, including (i) a requirement that equity FI clients disclose their exposure to coal, (ii) all FI clients exposed to high-risk sub-project disclose a summary of their environmental and social management system, (iii) a voluntary pilot project for FI clients to disclose all high risk sub-projects, and (iv) a “green equity approach” that would result in FI clients reducing or exiting all coal investments over a defined period. A significant portion of IFC's lending is through financial intermediaries. It has always been a loophole through which the IFC can finance projects with significant adverse impacts. SOMOs Publication of Out of the Dark with Bank Information Center Europe contributed to this reform.
*(1) The IAMs network developed a toolkit on assessing and addressing reprisals risks (presented in January 2019). This toolkit seeks to help IAMs approach the risk of reprisals, providing suggested actions, examples and tools that can be used to assess and address reprisals more efficiently and effectively. Through lobby meetings with DFIs and IAMs, voicing HRD concerns throughout IAMs complaints procedures, and through public advocacy within the Coalition for Human Rights in Development, SOMO has pushed for the IAMs to adopt measures to prevent and address reprisals against complainants. SOMO has collaborated on these lobby and advocacy efforts with several partners including CEE Bankwatch, OT Watch, Birlesik, CIEL, FUNDEPS, and Arab Watch Coalition. There was no change in policy prior to the development of the toolkit. Rather, the toolkit resulted from the realization among IAMs that reprisals against HRDs (incl. complainants) is a problem IAMs must deal with in their work. The toolkit forms the guidance by which IAMs should adapt their practice.

4 policies improved or introduced by public financial (development) institutions on accountability, transparency and human rights due diligence policies adopted that advance socially just and sustainable development in LLMICs including: 1) protocols on human rights defenders adopted by The World Bank Inspection Panel and Compliance Advisor Ombudsman (CAO) of the IFC. SOMO advoacted for the protocols, analysed the draft policy and suggested improvements; 2) The World Bank Inspection Panel improved its policy on disclosure of its findings regarding compliance of the World Bank with its own policies. The new policy allows it to share the summary of conclusions (i.e. Table of Findings) with complainants. 3) In October 2016, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) adopted a policy (via a Memorandum of Understanding with the International Trade Union Confederation) to improve EBRD clients’ implementation of EBRD’s Performance Requirements related to labor and working conditions (inclunding freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining) and to health and safety standards. SOMO contributed to the result by supporting complainants in the only labor rights complaint thus far filed to the EBRD’s accountability mechanism (PCM). The complaint, in combination with related communication by the complainant to the EBRD, revealed the shortcomings in EBRD policy for ensuring clients’ compliance with the bank’s standards. 4) The Interamerican Development Bank (IDB's) MICI (Independent Consultation and Investigation Mechanism of the IDB) officially installed an external stakeholder advisory board in the summer of 2016, which will serve as an official channel for civil society to provide input on the functioning of the mechanism. SOMO contributed to the result by advocating for a stakeholder board (e.g. in the report Glass Half Full) and by supporting a CSO in Argentina
